text:
In this episode of Speaking of Chemistry,
we’re going to find out
just how bad my sweat smells.

And we’ll get to that soon enough, but where
our story actually starts is with a bandage
that fights bacterial infections.
With electricity.
Maybe.

This bandage, sold as Procellera, looks and
feels like a regular cloth bandage, but it

costs a little more, presumably because of
its electrical powers.

A box of three bandages like this goes for
about $48 a pop.

The bandage is covered with little zinc and
silver dots.

When moistened with an electrolyte—fluid
from a wound, for example—contact with the

dots creates a small voltage, allowing electrons
to flow from zinc anodes to silver cathodes.
Early batteries used this same idea.

Those were made of two different plates—like
zinc and copper—stacked on top of one another.

Sandwiched between each plate was cloth or
paper soaked with an electrolyte.

Basic battery design is what inspired Jeff
Skiba when he invented the bandage prototype
10 years ago.

Jeff Skiba: And so I thought, what if I took
the battery apart in three dimensions, and
then I laid it on a flat surface.
Tien: And recently, studies have shown that the electric bandage can kill bacteria that infect wounds.
How exactly it does that is up for debate.

But however it happens, keeping bacteria away
from wounds is what you want.

Mina Izadjoo: Wound healing and treating the
infection, they go hand in hand.

Control of the bad bugs in that wound site
is critical to have improved wound healing,

to have less scarring, and to have a better
patient outcome.
Tien:  That’s Mina Izadjoo.
She works in the private sector now, but for more than a decade she researched wound care

technology, including Procellera, for the
military.

She’s also served as a consultant for Vomaris,
which makes the bandage.

Izadjoo says the beauty of the bandage is
that one, it doesn’t need an external power

source, and two, it offers doctors another
way to treat infections, which can be deadly,
as bacteria have developed resistance to drugs.

The CDC reports more than 23,000 annual deaths
in the U.S. from antibiotic-resistant infections.

Working with Vomaris in 2014, Izadjoo’s
lab isolated drug-resistant strains of bacteria
from the wounds of military personnel.

The electric bandage stopped these microbes
from growing or killed them outright.

Last year, Chandan Sen and his group at Ohio
State University showed the bandage also prevents
biofilm bacterial infections in lab animals.

Biofilms are like gooey shields that bacteria
come together to make.

Bacteria in these films are notoriously resistant
to antibiotic drugs.

Biofilms also cling to surfaces, which can
lead to really resilient infections when those

surfaces are things like bed sores or embedded
medical devices.

So how does this bandage bust up biofilms
and other bacterial infections?

Findings from Sen’s lab suggest that the
electric field does two things.

For one, it activates oxygen and turns it
into a bacteria-blasting missile.

For another, it disrupts the signals that
bacteria send to each other that say, “Hey!
Let’s build a biofilm.”

We should note that some of these studies
were partly funded by Vomaris.

We also asked Sen about a potential wrinkle:
Silver by itself is used as an antibiotic
in a number of products today.

So what if it’s just the silver dots that
are doing all the work?
Sen says that’s not the case.

His lab ran control experiments in which they
treated a biofilm with three separate bandages:

one placebo, one with silver and zinc, and
one with just silver.

Only the bandage with silver and zinc effectively
killed the bacteria.

I talked to biochemist Vincent Rotello of
the University of Massachusetts, Amherst,

who still wasn’t completely convinced about
the mechanism.

Rotello suggested two more control experiments
that would help rule out the metals’ acting
on their own.

One is to switch out the silver dots for another
metal like gold.

Another is to test the bandage with just zinc
dots.

I asked Izadjoo what she thought of the mechanism,
and she says it might be silver and the electric

current’s powers combined that’s killing
the bacteria.

So far we’ve seen petri dish and animal
studies with these electric bandages.
But what about its effectiveness in people?

Soon, a clinical trial at the San Antonio
Military Medical Center will test the product’s
efficacy at treating patient burns.

But doctors are already using the product
to try to fight antibiotic-resistant infections,
particularly in sports medicine.

The bandage makers think their product could
also help athletes’ performance and have

incorporated the silver and zinc pattern into
sportswear.

Vomaris is conducting studies of the shirts
with endurance athletes.

In one small study, Vomaris was surprised
to find that 90% of the athletes felt odor-free

or less smelly than usual after working out
in the shirts.

CEO Michael Nagel attributes this to the material’s
ability to kill odor-causing bacteria.

That sounded pretty incredible, so I couldn’t
help but ask ...

Tien: Is it possible to get a T-shirt for
our video?
Michael Nagel: Yeah, I’ll look and see if we’ve got an extra one to send you. Absolutely.
Tien: So here we are.

To see for ourselves whether the electroactive
shirt actually works, we had to figure out
just how bad I smell.

First, as a control, I worked out wearing
a normal shirt with a similar texture.

Then the next day I did the same thing with
the fancy electroactive shirt.

It took me about 25 minutes both times to
get this sweaty.

Then we found some brave souls for a subjective
smell test.
Tien: Do you guys smell anything?
Manny: Should I smell something?

We waited a few hours post-workout to give
the odor-producing bacteria time to proliferate.

Then my very dedicated Speaking of Chem cohosts
rated the smell of both shirts on a point

scale, where zero is neutral, 10 smells like
a delicious meal, and –10 is rotten fish.
First up, the control shirt.

It scored a –3 from Kerri and a –4 from
Manny.

They described the smell as similar to sour
milk.
Now the moment of truth.

The electric shirt came in at –2.5 from
Kerri and 0 from Manny.
He said it just smelled like a normal shirt.
So there you have it, folks.

The marginally satisfying results of an off-the-cuff,
so not-blinded experiment.
Special thanks go to Sarah Everts, the sage of sweat science, for her insights on the smell test.

And of course to Vomaris for giving us this
shirt, which we’ve washed and will be donating
to Goodwill.
And thanks to you for watching.

For more experimental adventures with
